msDesc.head: Isidore, Rupert of Deutz, William of Malmesbury, Drogo of Laon, Bernold of Konstsnz; etc.

msItem.note: Foreleaves: fols. ir-iir blank; fol. iiv, contents-list and number.

physDesc.p: The whole volume is made up of texts that complement each other, with shared scribes and a shared style of initial throughout, but it divides into three parts, 1: fols. 1-24, 2: fols. 25-122, and 3: fols. 123-54, which were written as separate units then put together.

extent.measure: Written on 154 membrane leaves preceded by two medieval flyleaves.

collation.catchwords: Catchwords, mostly not by the scribe of the text, are on most quires.

supportDesc.condition: Major initials have been excised from fols. 1r (two) and 25r.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in two columns, each 265-70 80, 45 lines. Pricked in inner and outer margins, ruled in pencil, and folded HSOS.

handDesc.handNote: Good protogothic bookhand. Parts 1 and 3 are in a round, rather grand script, probably by one scribe.
Part 2, probably by more than one scribe, is less grand but still of high quality. Punctuation is by low point.

decoDesc.decoNote: Major initials have been excised from fols. 1r (two) and 25r. Remaining initials are plain but large (four/nine-line) and in strong colours, red, blue, green; one on fol. 117r is in gold without colour and one on fol. 96v is red, infilled in red and blue.
Descenders of some long letters are patterned with white.
There are grotesques in some lower margins.

binding.p: Sewn on three double bands between heavy square-edged flush oak boards covered with white alum-tawed sheepskin. On the front cover are the remains of two straps, the lower stained red, each one held by five nails of the usual type. On the outer edge, between the remains of the straps, a large recess was chiselled out of the wood, perhaps for an earlier single strap-and-pin fastening, but it was never used. On the back cover the catch for the upper strap has been lost but the lower remains. At the bottom are six holes from a chain-plate (position 1), also, on the edge, two holes from another chain-plate (position 5). On the spine is a lozenge-shaped label with 2 on it. The endbands are blue and white, edges are yellowed, and there is a foreedge title.

origin.p: A fine book from a monastic scriptorium.

history.provenance: On fol. 154v is Liber ys(?), in a documentary hand of s. xiiex or xiiiin followed by Westmr in a more formal script in different ink, probably over erasure but not of a very different date. On fol. iiv are the titles of the works in the volume, in three hands of ss. xv and xvi, the second, a fine italic of s. xvi, found also in MSS 20 and 29. Ker, All Souls, List 1, no. 19, with books in King Henry's gift. No. 20 in James, Ecloga, and no. 1435 (34) in CMAM.
history.acquisition: At the bottom of fol. 1r is ex libris style 5, Liber Collegii animarum omnium fidelium Oxonie ex dono Regis Henrici viti. Oretis pro Inclito statu eiusdem in a hybrida formata hand of s. xv. All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on front pastedown, vv.1.8 and ww:4:2 (both deleted), MS. 28 (figure added), 151 (pencil), and bookplate no. 8 with L.R. 1.e.7. written on it in pencil; on fol. iiv is 20; on fol. ir, 5..10 (pencil).

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.

msItem.rubric: Incipit epistola ysidori hispalensis archiepiscopi in libro primo de ecclesiasticis officiis. fol. 1r
msItem.incipit: Domino meo dei seruo Fulgentio fol. 1r
Ea que in officiis ecclesiasticis celebrantur fol. 1r
msItem.explicit: ut sermo noster paternis sentenciis firmaretur. fol. 22r
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber .iius. Sancti isidori de officiis ecclesiasticis. fol. 22r
msItem.author: Isidore
msItem.title: De ecclesiasticis officiis
msItem.note: Isidore, De ecclesiasticis officiis, ed. C. H. Lawson, CCSL 113 (1989), who records but does not use this manuscript; CPL 1207.

msItem.rubric: Incipit ordo officiorum Qui agitur in ecclesia Romana. fol. 22r
msItem.incipit: Feria quarta nouissime ebdomade aduentus statio colligitur hora ixa. Ad sanctam mariam maiorem dicitur introitus rorate. stante archidiacono et sub-diacono in suis fuscis coculis fol. 22r
msItem.explicit: De hinc dicto agnus dei. et communione et oratione. disceditur post ite missa est. fol. 24v
msItem.title: Ordo officiorum qui agitur in ecclesia Romana
msItem.note: An unidentified text which follows item i(i) without an intervening space but begins with a major initial. It is found with items i(i) and 2-4 in London, Lambeth Palace, MS 363 and with items 2-4 in Lambeth Palace, MS 380, from Lanthony (which now also includes item i but as a later, Lanthony, addition).

supportDesc.foliation: Part 1 has a catchword only on its first quire (quire 2 of the complete volume) but its leaves have numerous page numberings or letterings: in quire 2 pages are numbered i—xvi (with some losses) in small red roman figures in bottom corners; in quire 3 pages have small red letters a—i (with some losses) in bottom corners; in quire 4 pages have small ink letters [] b c [] e—g m p in bottom corners.

msItem.rubric: Incipit proemium in librum de ecclesiasticis institucionibus. fol. 25r
msItem.incipit: a que per anni circulum ordine constituto in diuinis aguntur officiis E fol. 25r
msItem.rubric: Explicit proemium. Incipit de diuinis officiis. Capitulum primum. fol. 25r
msItem.explicit: Quorum quanto occulcior pugna. tanto difficilior uictoria. 122r
msItem.author: Rupert of Deutz
msItem.title: De ecclesiasticis officiis
msItem.note: Rupert of Deutz, De ecclesiasticis officiis, ed. H. Haacke, CCCM 7 (1967), in which this manuscript is A13 and is described at p. xxix. See id., 'Die Uberlieferung der Schriften Ruperts von Deutz', Deutsches Archiv fur Erfirschung des Mittelalters, 16 (1960), 397-436. Our text omits the author's letter to Cuno bp. of Regensburg, pr. Haacke, CCCM 7, 1-4, and begins with the prologue. There are some marginal annotations and distinctiones in hands of ss. xiiex and xiii. Four erased lines in the lower margin of fol. 50r are not recoverable by ultraviolet light. Fol. 122v is blank.

supportDesc.collation: Part 2 shows most signs of organization, with large quire numbers I-IIII on the last versos of the first four quires (quires 5—8 of the complete volume) and X and XI on its tenth and eleventh quires (quires 14 and 15 of the complete volume). IIII is in red and is perhaps done by the rubricator. Throughout part 2 are catchwords, none, probably, in the hand of the scribe of the text. In part 2 a small red a is on fol. 25v, the first leaf of quire 5, suggesting a continuation of the system in part 1, abandoned when it was observed how many catchwords and quire signatures had been used in it.

msItem.rubric: Incipit prefatio Willelmj in abreviatione amalarij fol. 123r
msItem.explicit: qui catholice de talibus scripsit animum intende. fol. 123r
msItem.rubric: Expliciunt Capitula. Incipit liber Willelmj in abreuiatione Amalarij.fol. 123r
msItem.incipit: Antiquus ecclesie mos fuit iam inde ab apostolorum seruatus temporibus fol. 123r
msItem.explicit: Fuerit fortassis aliquis qui inde scripserit desertius. nemo certe peritius. fol. 136v
msItem.author: William of Malmesbury
msItem.title: Abbreviatio Amalarii de ecclesiasticis officiis
msItem.note: William of Malmesbury, Abbreviatio Amalarii de ecclesiasticis officiis, ed. mainly from this manuscript (MS 0, one of five) by R. W. Pfaff, The 'Abbreviatio Amalarii' of William of Malmesbury, RTAM 47 (1980), 77-113; 48 (1981), 128-71. Three extracts (from fols. 123r, 129v, 134v) pr. by W. Stubbs, Willelmi Malmesbiriensis monachi de gestis regum anglorum, i (RS 90; London, 1887), pp. cxxviii-cxxx. For the Amalarius text see J. M. Hanssens, Amalarii episcopi opera liturgica omnia (Studi e testi 138, 1948).

msItem.rubric: Incipient capitula libri Ivonis canotensis episcopi de ecclesiasticis officiis fol. 136v
Expliciunt Capitula. Incipit liber Ivonis Carnotensis episcopi de ecclesiasticis officiis. fol. 137r
msItem.incipit: Dominus Filios israhel de dura seruitute egipti fol. 137r
msItem.author: Drogo of Laon
msItem.title: De divinis officiis

msItem.rubric: De introitu ad missam. ix. fol. 139r
msItem.incipit: Presbiter cum se parat ad missam iuxta romanam consuetudinem fol. 139r
msItem.rubric: De dominicali officio non facile pretermittendo. fol. 153v
msItem.incipit: Missam beatus petrus primum celebrasse fertur antiochie fol. 153v
msItem.quote: ad huc fieri solet. Ignatius antiochie sirie tercius post petrum episcopus fol. 154r
msItem.author: Bernold of Konstanz or St Blasien (Ps.-Ivo Carnotensis)
msItem.title: De officiis seu Micrologus de ecclesiasticis observationibus

msItem.note: A conflation of two texts. (a) Drogo of Laon, De divinis officiis, pr. PL 161166. 1557-64; and (b) Bernold of Konstanz or St Blasien (Ps.-Ivo Carnotensis), De officiis seu Micrologus de ecclesiasticis observationibus, pr. PL 151. 977-1022. The text was first published in Paris in 1510. D. S. Baumer, 'L'Auteur du Micrologue', Revue benedictine, 8 (1891), 193-201, prints (as chs. 63 and 64) Missam beati petrus primum celebrasse to the end of our text, which occurs only in English manuscripts and is not in PL. For the establishment of Bernold as the author see G. Morin, 'Que "l'auteur du Micrologue" est Bernold de Constance', Revue benedictine, 8 (1891), 385-95. See further V. L. Kennedy, 'For a New Edition of the Micrologus of Bernold of Constance', Melanges en l'honneur de Monseigneur Michel Andrieu(Strasbourg, 1956), 228-41; M. Manitius, Geschichte der lateinischen Literatur des Mittelalters, 3 vols. (Munich, 1911-31), iii. 404-7 and references; J. R. Geiselmann, Bernold von St. Blasien: Sein neuentdecktes Werk über die Eucharistie (Munich, 1936), esp. 22-32. Fol. 154v is blank except for notes of s. xiiex or xiiiin (see History).

supportDesc.collation: Part 3 has no catchwords, quire numbers or signatures, page numbers or letters.
